titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to The Leo Deaner Radical Left-Wing Publications collection, 1890-2017 LAC0011
titlestmt.author: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

publicationstmt.publisher: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-05-05 14:26:18 -0400.

repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.unittitle: The Leo Deaner Radical Left-Wing Publications collection
did.abstract: This collection is composed of 20th and early 21st century American radical Left-Wing publication material. It is comprised mainly of various printed material, including pamphlets, newsletters, journals and flyers dating from 1890-2017. The individuals and groups represented in these publications were active in the American labor, anti-war, black power and radical student movements. Many of them espoused a proletarian revlutionary agenda. In 2009, Leo Deaner donated a collection of books and pamphlets related to the radical left-wing movements in America. Numerous donations followed this initial one. The books donated by Mr. Deaner are cataloged and housed in the Special Collections book collection. For locating these books use the GW Libraries online catalog. The pamphlets, flyers, and newsletters donated by Mr. Deaner became this collection. To compliment and deepen the research value of Mr. Deaner's donations the Labor History Research Center staff have purchased additional materials and added them to this collection. Leo Deaner is a longtime trade unionist and political activist. He joined Teamsters Local 776 located in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania in 1968 after serving in the US Army. He served the local as an elected Business Agent for a number of years. While attending Harrisburg Area Community College and the University of California at Berkeley he played leadership roles in the progressive movements of that era. Most recently Mr. Deaner has served since 1999 as a senior staff member of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters reporting directly to the General President.
did.physloc: Materials are stored off-site, and will require additional retrieval time. Please contact the Special Collections Research Center for more information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection, composed of material from a number of different sources, offers researchers a unique look at the 20th and early 21st century American Left. It is comprised mainly of various printed material, including pamphlets, newsletters, journals and flyers dating from 1890-2017.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five series: Pamphlets by title: Old Left [arrangement aphabetical], Pamphlets by title: Old Left [arrangement loosely chronological], Pamphlets by title: New Left [arrangement alphabetical], Pamphlets by title: New Left [arrangement chronological], and Pamphlets by topic

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Please cite unpublished materials in the following way:
Please provide the title and date of item, catalog number (if applicable it will be found written on the folder), name of the collection, name of the repository, and location of the repository.

Example:James Oglethorpe to the Trustees, 13 January 1876, RG0001 Series 1, Box 4, Folder 3. Records of the Board of Trustees, Special Collections Research Center, Gelman Library, The George Washington University, Washington, D.C.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The core of this collection is a series of donations made by Leo Deaner beginning in in 2009. Over the course of three years Mr. Deaner donated a significant number of books and pamphlets on the New Left and the Black Liberation and anti-Vietnam War movements. This orignal donation from Mr. Deaner has been made subsequent donations multiple times per year since 2015 of purchased pamphlets.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The final arrangement of this collection is unusual and reflective of the fact that the materials in this collection have arrived at the library in many separate donations from different donors and over time a variety of arrangement schemes have been used.

did.unittitle: Pamphlets by title: Old Left [arrangement alphabetical]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains radical left wing publications dating from 1910-1959. Roughly falling into the category of the "Old Left," the majority of these pamphlets and journals were published by the Communist Party, USA, the Socialist Party, USA and the Socialist Labor Party. Others were published by the Young People's Socialist League, the Communist League, and the Workers Party.

The topics covered in the publications vary, but most are related in some way to communist and socialist thought on labor, capitalism and the working class; some are party propaganda and recruitment tools while others lay out more theoretical arguments. Also included are publications related to the Second Red Scare, including Senate reports and pamphlets advocating for the civil liberties of communists and socialists, and materials opposing the United States' involvement in World War II. Other pamphlets detail the history of the labor movement, communist party and the international labor holiday known as May Day. Also of particular note are six issues of "The New Masses" magazine, dating from 1934-1936, including an issue from May Day, 1934.

Also worth noting in this series are the numerous publications authored by important communist and socialist figures of the day. These include Daniel DeLeon, Mary Marcy, William Z. Foster and Earl Browder.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is composed of various printed material, including pamphlets, newspapers, newsletters, journals and flyers, produced by and about radical left-wing organizations and issues dating from 1960-2007. Most of the materials date from the New Left era, between the years of 1960 and 1980.

The publications vary widely in topic and purpose. Some of the themes covered are the anti-war and anti-imperialist movements, the Black Power movement, women's liberation, communist theory, unionism, prisons and the prison abolition movement, the student movement, movement history, as well as contemporary news and issues. Also included are communist party propaganda, reprints of classic radical writings, as well as original publications including Students for a Democratic Society's "Port Huron Statement," the University of California, Berkeley's "Disorientation" guide from 1970, and "How Harvard Rules," published by the Africa Research Group.

Further, the materials were published by and about a wide range of organizations, from Maoist and Marxist-Leninist communist factions, to Black Power organizations, to student groups. Among others, these include the Black Panther Party, the Black Workers Congress, Students for a Democratic Society, the Weather Underground, the Industrial Workers of the World, the Revolutionary Union / Revolutionary Communist Party, USA, the Sojourner Truth Organization, Vietnam Veterans Against the War, the Venceremos Brigade (Cuba), the Movement of the Revolutionary Left Movement (Chile), and the Tupamaros (Uruguay). Also included are a number of pamphlets published in Peking by Foreign Languages Publishers on Maoist thought and practice.

Also worth noting are publications detailing contemporary events, issues and movements. These include the 1960s free speech movement at the University of California, Berkeley, the 1968 Columbia University protests, and the 1971 murder of George Jackson and subsequent trial of the San Quentin Six.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is composed of various printed material, including pamphlets, newspapers, newsletters, journals and flyers, produced by and about radical left-wing organizations and issues dating from 1972-1996. Most of the materials date from the New Left era, between the years of 1960 and 1980.

The publications vary widely in topic and purpose. Some of the themes covered are the anti-war and anti-imperialist movements, the Black Power movement, women's liberation, communist theory, unionism, prisons and the prison abolition movement, the student movement, movement history, as well as contemporary news and issues. Also included are communist party propaganda, reprints of classic radical writings, as well as original publications including Students for a Democratic Society's "Port Huron Statement," the University of California, Berkeley's "Disorientation" guide from 1970, and "How Harvard Rules," published by the Africa Research Group.

Further, the materials were published by and about a wide range of organizations, from Maoist and Marxist-Leninist communist factions, to Black Power organizations, to student groups. Among others, these include the Black Panther Party, the Black Workers Congress, Students for a Democratic Society, the Weather Underground, the Industrial Workers of the World, the Revolutionary Union and Revolutionary Communist Party, USA.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes pamphlets, newspapers, newsletters, articles, and fliers related to radical left subjects and organizations that date from circa 1890 to 2017.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into six subseries: Organizations, Publications, publishers, and presses, Movements, Events and issues, People, and Geographic Regions.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The subseries designated within this series are reflective of very broad catetories assigned by the donor and it is likely that many of the pamphlets can fit into more than one of these subseries. Each folder includes a list of the pamphlets housed within it. Therefore the best method to locate appropriate research materials in this series and the others is to to search by pamphlet title, author, or keyword.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contents of Folder: G.I. Defense Organization CAll to a National Anti-war Conference Request for delegate status Steering Committee proposal for joint majority-minority resolution G.I. Defense Organization

scopecontent.head: Contents in folder include:
scopecontent.p: All of these relate to the Vietnam War: Sign the Agreement Stop the War; flier: Use your Lunch Hour to Speak Out Against the War; A call for help support the resistance; Vietnam is not negotiable; Operation Total Victory February, 1971; The war and its roots Vietnam and American Imperialism; On the necessity of revolution David Harris; The Fort Hood Three; The Ally April 1971

scopecontent.head: Contents in folder include:
scopecontent.p: Notes on organizing by Charles McLaurin; My Name is Wesley Roberts Wells. Includes Black Panther Party and Black Liberation topics.

scopecontent.head: Contents in folder include:
scopecontent.p: John Willie Reed Driver Slain After His Car Invades Yard by Charles Longstreet Weltner; The Gentleman from Mississippi our first negro senator by Elizabeth Lawson; Vietnam a thousand years of struggle by Terry Cannon; A new look at U.S. investments in Latin America by Edie Black; American economic imperialism a survey of the literature by Wiliam Caspary; The contradiction of advanced capitalist society and its resolution by Martin Nicolaus; Scarce resources the dynamic of american imperialism by Heather Dean; Democracy and the university by Richard K. Pope; The iceberg strategy universities and the military-industrial complex by Martin Nicolaus; Statement of Association of California State College Professors; Free Speech movement at UC Berkeley documents; Behind the battle of Berkeley the mind of Clark Kerr published by the Independent Socialist Club; GI's March Oct 12 Task Force Vol. 1 No. 2; GI's March September 21 Task Force Vol. 1 No. 1; Task Force free to GI's Vol. 1 No. 3; Move on Moffett Field United with Ellis Street Workers support GI resistence; GI armed forces day picnic

scopecontent.head: Contents of folder:
scopecontent.p: Most of the pamphlets in this folder relate to the topics of black liberation, womens liberation, and prison movements: The Negroes in a Soviet America by James W. Ford and James S. Allen; On organizing the Masses #1 Electoral politics: its problems and prospects by Bill Epton; The Legacy of Slavery and the roots of Black Nationalism by Eugene D. Genovese; Strategies and tactics for confronting mounting racism from Black Liberation Press; Racism and the black national thesis by Robert Allen; Riot Data Review sniping incidents a new pattern of violence; Female liberation as the basis for social revolution by Roxanne Dunbar; Women of the new world; Organizing Women a speech by Laurie Zoloth of Oakland; presented at the Juche Conference San Jose; The prison industrial complex and the global economy by Eve Goldberg and Linda Evans; Boston campus draft opposition; Building a chapter of the New American Movement; MIM Theory a White Proletariat?; The retreat from black nationalism: a response by Robert L. Allen by Harold Baron

scopecontent.head: Contents of folder:
scopecontent.p: All these materials related to the GI Movement: Announcing a new social and political action group the USMC; The Airman's Voice Dec 1969, June 1970, August 1970; Open Ranks Vol. 1 No. 9; The Bond various issues 1969-1970

scopecontent.head: Contents of folder:
scopecontent.p: All of these pamphlets relate to the topic of GI Movement: Open Sights by GI's for GI's Vol. II No. 4, Vol II No. 5, Vol. II No. 6; The Pawn Vol. II No. 1; Up Against the Bulkhead Vol. I No. 4; Worker & Soldier incorporating wildcat report & wildcat, No. 1; Bragg Briefs GI's United Vol. 3, No. 6; Fort Lewis Free Press Vol. 1 No. 1; Counter-Attack 2nd issue

scopecontent.head: Contents of folder:
scopecontent.p: The topics in this folder include women's liberation; prison movement; and the New Left: We may not have much, but there's a lot of us!; From Women in Prison Here to Women of Viet Nam we are sisters; Free Women a new university conference pamphlet; Women's liberation a New University Conference pamphlet; an end to the neglect of the problems of negro women by Claudia Jones; Youth and Law legal advice for youth; School of Community Organization Chicago; The Garrison Society by Vernon K. Dibble; Thought on the movement who does the movement move? by John McDermott; Imperialism: an exchange American Imperialism and the peace movement by Robert Wolfe and Socialism - the sustaining menace by Ronald Aronson; Peace Research & Education Project newsletter No. 4 January, April, and May 1964; Power in American Society by Jim Jacobs; campus rights handbook for the students, faculty, and staff of the university of maryland college park campus; Battlecry rock against the right; the fbi is in town . . . don't talk!; Paul Baran on Marxism

scopecontent.head: Contents in folder:
scopecontent.p: The broad topic of all these pamphlets is women's liberation: Witches midwives an nurses a history of women healers; In defense of the women's movement articles by Ruthann Miller, Mary Alice Waters, and Evevlyn Reed; Pioneers of women's liberation by Joyce Crowley; The traffic in women and other essays on feminism by Emma Goldman

scopecontent.head: Contents in folder include:
